body: Oops, should improve this somewhat

@finalName: oha... fixed
@-x-test.jar... puh ... right ... well ... couldn't you come up with any easier requests :-) I'll give it a shot and come back ASAP

I'm curious; the -test artifacts are not generated automatically? In addition there seams to be no -sources for them by now? (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-3975)? Should they be generated automatically and also with source?
WICKET-3975 is fixed. The ball is back in your field ;-)

done; ball is back :P

Basically I would say it works; BUT I'm curious about:

wicket-core-1.5-SNAPSHOT.jar
wicket-core-1.5-SNAPSHOT-sources.jar
wicket-core-1.5-SNAPSHOT-tests.jar
wicket-core-1.5-SNAPSHOT-test-sources.jar

I'm not sure which plugin does the thing but IMHO we should either use tests or test? (this is from the core; I've done it the same way for now. Once this is fixed in wicket I can rebase and adapt the behavior).
btw, sorry for the a little bit messed diff... this is because I use "git svn rebase". Since the mirror always needs some hours it happens that more commits than from me are in the diff :-(

The patches look good to me.

-tests.jar is produced by http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-jar-plugin/jar-mojo.html
-test-sources.jar by http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-source-plugin/test-jar-mojo.html
Both of them automatically append their suffixes to the configured 'finalName' setting. So it seems it is not possible to tweak them :-/

I'm not concerned about the "beauty" of this. I do not use this but does
e.g. eclipse (m2plugin) and/or other ides/tools find the corresponding
sources to the -tests.jar then? But I've checked the goals for myself now
and there seams to be no option to adapt the ending :-( Only option is to
create an issue; but issues for maven-plugins typically need ENDLESS to be
applied... so no solution for now.

Nevermind, for now it works. OK, a) should I put the -tests and
-tests-sources versions/dependency-references to the root pom? I'm not
completely sure about your conventions here b) create issue and apply
splashed patch?

Kind regards,
Andreas

a) don't put them in the parent pom because they are not used by all modules. I'll clean that after applying your patch.
b) attach the patch to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-3976

done; once the patch is applied I'll delete the branch and start a new one
for the most basic wicket-osgi impl. Thank you very much

Following Apache rules we have to wait the vote to end. Looking at the current votes I'm sure approach 2) will win so your work wont be lost.
If you don't want to wait then you can create a new branch on top of this one. You'll need just to add the new module in the parent pom, everything else will be in the new folder wicket-osgi, so I think it wont be hard for you to rebase after this patch is applied. But wicket-osgi can be added at any time so it is not urgent at all :-)
Thanks for your contributions!

wicket till 1.6 development starts on trunk/master :-)

@anpieber: 

the build fails with the patch applied with:

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.felix:maven-bundle-plugin:2.3.5:bundle (default-bundle) on project wicket: Execution default-bundle of goal org.apache.felix:maven-bundle-plugin:2.3.5:bundle failed: An API incompatibility was encountered while executing org.apache.felix:maven-bundle-plugin:2.3.5:bundle: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: java.lang.String.getBytes(Ljava/nio/charset/Charset;)[B

String.getBytes(Charset) is only in JDK1.6.

I found http://web.archiveorange.com/archive/v/EsaYErDQSRzpVlX0ZFsq
Will work with 2.3.4 for now.
The patch is applied with r1159963.
@anpieber: See my comment/question in the ticket.
@topping: can you please close this pull request because we don't have permissions.

Oh hell. I've only tested with 1.6.. I'll be home from paris this night and
give it a shot than. Kind regards, Andreas

The patch is applied. Thanks!
Since we (Wicket devs) don't own this repo I cannot close the pull request. But I guess GitHub will do it automatically once it realizes that the patch is applied.

The issue wont be closed automatically because this repo doesn't sync from our Apache Git repo, but from the old Apache SVN repo. So it will not get the new commit from yesterday ...
@michaelmosmann : only you and some Apache Infra guys can close this issue. The patch is applied only in master branch of our Apache Git repo.
ok, i close it. thanks..

Hi,

I just committed the change suggested by Andreas Pieber: <Export-Package>*</Export-Package>
Please test it and let us know whether it helps.
If everything is OK then please close this Pull Request since we don't own this repo and we are not able to do it.
Thanks!
Ok, perfect. Now I've been able to deploy wicket-extensions without any problem.
Added some logging fixes (less Exception.printStackTrace()) and removed some unused methods from wicket-datetime's DateConverter
Applied
6df7907 has been applied
The other commits were not committed (I didn't have the time to apply those and check them). Can you re-submit a pull request for the other commits?

Thanks Tom, I agree with the issue reporter that for security reasons the labels should escape their model value by default. I'll explain on WICKET-4219 why I don't see a need for further customizations.
applied to 'master' branch ... thanks for contributing :-)
Applied, thanks.
Applied, thanks!

The patch is applied.
Thanks!
I apologize.  I'm still new to git and github.  If the patch has been applied as you say, wouldn't I be able to see that commit on the master branch in github?

GitHub is a mirror of Apache Git repo. It is being updated few times per day.
We (the Wicket team) do not own https://github.com/apache/wicket and we cannot close this pull request.
Thank you!

Thanks!
Yes, it was included. Thanks.
How did you do this? Would like to know if there is a simple solution?

Unfortunately not too high tech. My IDE (NetBeans) displays missing `@Override`s with a red warning. This annoys me, and I am a firm believer in `@Override`. Just open each .java file, click on the "Add `@Override`" link and make sure formatting is right.

You could probably write something, but is it worth it?

> This annoys me, and I am a firm believer in @Override.
> I totally agree. I got some refactoring problems if @Override is missing (method renaming). So i searched for a way to fix the missing annotations, but found no easy way.
> 
> You could probably write something, but is it worth it?
> If your codebase is big...
For IDEA: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9030986/intellij-is-it-possible-to-add-overrrides-to-all-methods-of-a-particular-interf
Patch submitted on the Jira, closing this PR.
cool .. thanks

Please fix the white space noice.
The actual functional change is not visible due to the different formatting.

And additionally you have to attach the patch to the ticket in Apache Jira. This way you give Apache the permissions to use it.
GitHub is just a convenient mirror of Apache Git/SVN repositories.

Thanks for the patch!
Ok, I'll prepare the patch. But what do you mean with "fix the white space noice" ?
Ok, I see. I think that you mean that I was using blank space instead of tab character. I've solved this and an unwanted import and uploaded a patch to the ticket.

Yes, I've opened https:// github.com /apache/wicket/pull/22.patch (the link to this .patch file is in the mail notification. Remove the spaces which I inserted to make GitHub not linkify it) and I saw that the formatting is broken.

Thanks for the patch again! We will take a look at it soon.
Please test on Unix just in case something in the code itself is behaving in a platform dependent way.
Fixed the problem by removing the new line characters completely.
Please close the PR because we don't have the karma to do it.

Thanks for the PR!
Due to Apache politics you have to attach the code as a patch to Jira so you agree to contribute it.
I'll try to take a look at the modifications tomorrow.

According to java.lang.ClassLoader#getResource()'s javadoc: ```

The name of a resource is a '/'-separated path name that identifies the resource. ``` I think your patch is invalid. Do you experience any problems ? Failing tests or failing build ? Please paste the errors here.

The patch is applied!
Please close this PR since we cannot do it.
Thanks!
Thank you!
I cannot apply your patch against current master. Can you rebase it please ?
I think I solved the problem. Only the patches in pom.xml files were causing problems.

The improvements are committed and will be part of the next release (Wicket 6.4.0/ Native WebSocket 0.5).
There are some minor differences so you may need to fix your application(s) too.

I didn't want to add IWebSocketSettings in wicket-core because it wont be able to manage anything WebSocket specific because wicket-core cannot depend on wicket-native-websocket.

The sample application is updated and pushed in my blogs repository too.

Thanks for your contribution!

This patch wont be applied.
This will change the current behavior for no good reason. You can use Java Reflection to check your classes. PropertyResolver purpose is not to check - it should fail by throwing exception so developers see it and fix their property expressions.

Also see LazyModel in WicketStuff project - https://github.com/wicketstuff/core/wiki/LazyModel.

Please close this Pull Request because we don't own the project at GitHub and only the reporter can do it.

Ok np.
I would like to suggest to adjust the javadocs. 
It's confusing to read that it will return null, while it actually throws an exception when a getter/setter doesn't exist.

This will be done!
Thanks !
think, the problem is solved in the current version..

Thanks!
I did it a bit differently because a new markup sourcing strategy that extends org.apache.wicket.markup.html.panel.AssociatedMarkupSourcingStrategy may not need to register a tag name.
Additionally every instantiation of (Panel|Border)MSS will register the name again and again.

Please close this PR since we do not own the repository.
Thank you!
Thanks!
The assumption is that  url.isAbsolute() == (url.isFull() || url.isContextAbsolute())

Thanks for the patch!. I like the idea. However, EventSubscriptionInvoker could use a bit more documentation. Also, the return value of invoke does not seem to be used. I think it should either be void or it should be used. If you could address these minor issues, I'm ok with merging this.

Good eye on the return type. That was cruft from before AjaxRequestInitializer was introduced. I also improved the invoker javadoc. It didn't feel appropriate to describe our app's implementation, but FYI our listener interfaces can contain multiple parameters. We needed a separate invoker impl to extract them from the event payload into separate invoke args.
It seems Github does not automatically close pull requests when they are merged. Can you close this?
